name: Perineal talc exposure and risk of ovarian carcinoma

features.name: Conclusion
features.value: Exposure to talc, via sanitary napkins, direct application to the perineum, or both, was significantly associated with risk of ovarian carcinoma.

features.name: No. of subjects
features.value: 450 patients with borderline and invasive ovarian carcinoma and 564 population controls in metropolitan Toronto and nearby areas of southern Ontario, Canada

features.name: Relative risk
features.value: odds ratio [OR] 1.42, 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.08–1.86

features.name: Length of follow
features.value: Not available

features.name: Case-control study
features.value: Yes

features.name: Risk factors
features.value: Talc

features.name: Geographical location
features.value: Metropolitan Toronto and nearby areas of southern Ontario, Canada

features.name: Age range
features.value: 35-79 years

features.name: Source of funding
features.value: Research Grant 6613-1415-53 from the National Health Research and Development Program of Health Canada, awarded to Dr. Risch

features.name: Authors
features.value: Stella Chang, B.A. and Harvey A. Risch, M.D., Ph.D.

features.name: Conclusion
features.value: Women with any regular talc exposure were at an increased risk of ovarian carcinoma (odds ratio [OR] 1.42, 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.08 – 1.86). The use of cornstarch, or cornstarch sometimes and talc sometimes, did not yield a significant association with risk (cornstarch OR 0.31, 95% CI 0.06 – 1.66; cornstarch/talc OR 0.68, 95% CI 0.18 – 2.55).

features.name: Number of Subjects
features.value: 450 ovarian carcinoma cases and 564 population controls

features.name: Length of Follow
features.value: No such information is available.

features.name: Descriptive Characteristics
features.value: Descriptive Characteristics of Study Population with information about age, origin, race, length of schooling, number of full-term pregnancies, years of oral contraceptive use, months of lactation per pregnancy, tubal ligation or hysterectomy or a mother or sister with ovarian or breast carcinoma, etc.

features.name: Dusting Behaviors
features.value: Exposure to talc via regular application of talc to the perineum after showering or bathing increases the risk of ovarian carcinoma (OR 1.42, 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.08 – 1.86). A nonsignificant increase in odds was observed for talc exposure via sanitary napkins (OR 1.26, 95% CI 0.81 – 1.96).

features.name: Type of Exposure
features.value: More women reported applying talc to their bodies after bathing or showering than using talc on their sanitary napkins. Some 11.3% of cases and 8.7% of controls reported using talc on sanitary napkins. In total, 38.2% of cases and 32.4% of controls reported that they had, at some time, regularly used talc after bathing or showering.

features.name: Questionnaire
features.value: A questionnaire was developed to detail the medical and reproductive histories of the subjects. This questionnaire was administered during an in-person, in-home interview after informed consent was obtained. The questionnaire focused on menstrual characteristics, pregnancies, and hormone and contraceptive use. Questions about regular talc use and type of talc use, as well as questions from which information about duration and frequency of exposure could be derived, were included.

features.name: Controls and Case Participants
features.value: Population-based controls were identified through the Ontario Ministry of Finance. Information on name, address, age, and gender was obtained from the Enumeration Composite Record listings, which include all homeowners, tenants, and family members, i.e., all persons in the province. From this listing, women living in the study area during the same 3-year period as the cases were randomly selected. Controls were matched to the cases within 3 15-year age groups.

features.name: Interview
features.value: Initial contact by letter was followed up with phone calls to determine eligibility. Women with bilateral oophorectomy performed at least 1 year previously were excluded. Over, 873 eligible controls were identified. Of these women, 564 (64.5%) were interviewed. The remainder either refused to participate (30.2%), were too ill to participate (1.9%), or were lost to follow-up (3.2%).

features.name: Analysis
features.value: Analysis was performed by modeling the data through multiple unconditional logistic regression with the SAS statistical package. In addition to the variables of interest examined here, the models included indicator terms for the age categories of the frequency matching (35 – 49, 50 – 64, and 65 – 79 years), and age as a continuous variable was also included to adjust for residual age effects. Models also contained terms for total years of oral contraceptive use; number of full-term pregnancies; average duration of breastfeeding per pregnancy; and ever having had a tubal ligation, a hysterectomy, or a mother or sister with ovarian or breast carcinoma.

features.name: Conclusion
features.value: Possible association between talc exposure and ovarian carcinoma

features.name: Mean years of after-bath talc use
features.value:
32.9 for cases who had ever used talc after bathing and 35.4
for controls.

features.name: Trend for years of talc exposure and risk of ovarian carcinoma
features.value: Borderline-significant

features.name: Duration of talc use
features.value: Less than 30 years of talc use showed increased risk, relative to no talc exposure

features.name: Mean frequency of talc use
features.value:
14.6 applications per month for cases;
for controls, it was 17.2 applications per month.

features.name: Calendar time of exposure
features.value: Prior to 1970

features.name: Risk for invasive carcinoma
features.value: Statistically significant

features.name: Sanitary napkins and tampons
features.value: No significant trend in risk detected

features.name: Conclusion
features.value: Talc exposure is associated with an increased risk of ovarian carcinoma, especially invasive carcinomas, but questionable dose-response relationship was observed.

features.name: Relative Risk
features.value: 1.42 for any regular talc exposure (95% CI 1.08 – 1.86)

features.name: Commercial Talc Substitutes
features.value: When cornstarch was assessed in relation to risk of ovarian carcinoma, no associations were found.

features.name: Mode of Talc Exposure
features.value: Direct application to the perineum

features.name: Effect of Talc within Specific Histologic Subtypes
features.value: Talc exposure was associated with both invasive and borderline carcinomas, but only significant for invasive carcinomas.

features.name: Possible Mechanisms for the Role of Talc in the Etiology of Ovarian Carcinoma
features.value: Talc may become incorporated into inclusion cysts providing a favorable environment for carcinogenesis or may act in a manner similar to "incessant ovulation."

features.name: Differences in Talc Concentration among Various Powders
features.value: Not investigated in this study.

features.name: Possible Reporting Error and Bias
features.value: Reporting error in reported talc use and failure to interview all eligible case and control subjects may have led to bias.

features.name: Conclusion
features.value: The results of this study appear to support the contention that talc exposure increases risk of ovarian carcinoma. Further studies are needed to clarify the role of talc in the etiology of ovarian carcinoma.

features.name: Conclusion
features.value: No medical research paper provided.
